results.abstract: Sampling of Bob Hope's jokes together with bits of his biography; photo (M)

headline.main: Word for Word/Bob Hope; You Want Jokes? I've Got A Half Million of Them

results.snippet: IT is the delivery that most people remember, if they remember anything at all: chest out, golf club in hand, chewing gum in mouth, a breezy brio embracing the news of the day. ''Hey, how about that $30 million for Uday and Qusay,'' you can imagine...
results.lead_paragraph: IT is the delivery that most people remember, if they remember anything at all: chest out, golf club in hand, chewing gum in mouth, a breezy brio embracing the news of the day. ''Hey, how about that $30 million for Uday and Qusay,'' you can imagine Bob Hope saying, slipping smoothly into gear. ''Innat something?'' Hope, who died at 100 last week, was mostly style, some would say. ''Hope is not a comedian,'' Groucho Marx once said. ''He just translates what others write for him.''

results.abstract: Stephen Metcalf reviews book Open Shutters: Poems by Mary Jo Salter (M)
results.snippet: OPEN SHUTTERS   Poems.   By Mary Jo Salter.   79 pp. New York:   Alfred A. Knopf. $23.
results.lead_paragraph: OPEN SHUTTERS Poems. By Mary Jo Salter. 79 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $23.

results.abstract: Richard O Covey, co-chairman of independent panel monitoring resumption of space shuttle flights, doubts if panel will be able to measure NASA's efforts to change management culture, which investigators have identified as key to space shuttle Columbia disaster; former astronaut says that committee will advise NASA on complying with specific recommendations, that remaining shuttle flights can never be made completely safe and that safety will have to be balanced with necessities of International Space Station (M)

headline.main: Shuttle Flights May Resume Before NASA Culture Changes

results.snippet: The co-chairman of an independent panel monitoring the resumption of space shuttle flights said today that it would probably be unable to measure NASA's efforts to change its management culture. The conclusion comes even though the board...
results.lead_paragraph: The co-chairman of an independent panel monitoring the resumption of space shuttle flights said today that it would probably be unable to measure NASA's efforts to change its management culture. The conclusion comes even though the board investigating the loss of the shuttle Columbia has identified management problems as being equal in importance to the specific physical causes of the crash. The co-chairman, Richard O. Covey, a retired Air Force colonel and astronaut who flew the first shuttle mission after the Challenger disaster in 1986, said his committee would stick to a ''narrow and focused'' effort to advise NASA on complying with recommendations of the investigative board, which is to issue its report on Aug. 26.

results.snippet: INTERNATIONAL   A2-7    Security Guard Killed In Iraqi Fuel Riots  Fuel riots continued in Basra, where a private security guard employed by the occupying forces was shot and killed by unidentified assailants. The severe fuel shortages plaguing...
results.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A2-7 Security Guard Killed In Iraqi Fuel Riots Fuel riots continued in Basra, where a private security guard employed by the occupying forces was shot and killed by unidentified assailants. The severe fuel shortages plaguing southern Iraq could recur elsewhere in the country, officials said. A1 Within the next few years, hundreds of thousands of refugees are expected to return home to Iraq, but because of the country's precarious condition, the occupying powers have insisted that the refugees be resettled slowly. A7

results.abstract: Fran Schumer Jersey column on astronauts Mark and Scott Kelly, natives of West Orange, NJ, who are only twins and only blood relatives to have flown in space; drawing (M)

headline.main: Outer Space, by Way of West Orange

results.snippet: BESS KELLY, the sweet woman you may have noticed behind the cash register at the StockPot restaurant in Montclair, doesn't like the limelight, but if you ask why she has pictures of astronauts on the wall, she'll admit that they're her great-nephews...
results.lead_paragraph: BESS KELLY, the sweet woman you may have noticed behind the cash register at the StockPot restaurant in Montclair, doesn't like the limelight, but if you ask why she has pictures of astronauts on the wall, she'll admit that they're her great-nephews and the only twins in the world to have flown in outer space. Mark and Scott Kelly, natives of West Orange and 1982 graduates of what was then Mountain High School, are, in fact, the only blood relatives who have been in outer space.

results.abstract: Profile of Albert DeMatteo, 15, as he tries out for Somers High School varsity football team; DeMatteo's brother, Anthony, was star wide receiver despite having only one arm and his father, Tony, is perhaps most successful coach in local high school football history; photo (M)

headline.main: Latest Family Recruit In a Football Heritage

results.snippet: THE high school football season started last week and on the first day of practice, a pocket-sized freshman here could be found carrying three things: his Tuskers helmet, the weight of family history and high hopes.     Unlike many of the muscled...
results.lead_paragraph: THE high school football season started last week and on the first day of practice, a pocket-sized freshman here could be found carrying three things: his Tuskers helmet, the weight of family history and high hopes. Unlike many of the muscled upperclassmen trying out for the Somers High School varsity team, Albert DeMatteo, 15, is a wisp of a boy.

results.abstract: Joe Glickman travel article on three-week climb on Alaska's Mount McKinley; photos; map; chart (L)
results.snippet: AT 1:18 a.m., Vern Tejas, an Alaskan mountaineering legend, stood outside my tent in his one-piece red down suit, singing a child's song loud enough to stir the dead: ''Up in the sky, the little bird flies. Down in the nest, the little birds rest.'' ...
results.lead_paragraph: AT 1:18 a.m., Vern Tejas, an Alaskan mountaineering legend, stood outside my tent in his one-piece red down suit, singing a child's song loud enough to stir the dead: ''Up in the sky, the little bird flies. Down in the nest, the little birds rest.'' It was the third day of our three-week climb on 20,320-foot Mount McKinley, the mountain that native Alaskans and most climbers call Denali, the Great One. We were at base camp, 7,200 feet up on the Kahiltna Glacier. Two dozen brightly colored tents dotted the vast, crevassed slope like beach towels on the dunes of the Sahara. Looming 15 miles in the distance, the south face of Denali seemed nearly close enough to touch.

results.abstract: Families of seven astronauts who died in Feb 1 breakup of space shuttle Columbia are dealing with their grief and loss as investigators prepare to issue their report on accident's cause; most families say they think investigation has been thorough and that they hope NASA makes changes that will make a difference (M)

headline.main: Awaiting Report, Families of Columbia's Astronauts Deal With Losses

results.snippet: Evelyn Husband's memories of her husband, Rick, the commander of the space shuttle Columbia, are still vivid. He took his job very seriously, but when he came home each night, his family was his focus.    He was able to set work aside ''and be a...
results.lead_paragraph: Evelyn Husband's memories of her husband, Rick, the commander of the space shuttle Columbia, are still vivid. He took his job very seriously, but when he came home each night, his family was his focus. He was able to set work aside ''and be a tremendous father and husband and that's why I miss him so much,'' Ms. Husband said of her spouse, her voice cracking. ''He would immediately start playing with the kids, help Laura with her homework, get on the floor and wrestle with Matthew, help me with dinner. He was totally devoted to us.''

results.abstract: X Prize competition is generating new interest in private sector space flight, with at least two dozen teams from five countries working on different designs, some in early production and testing; Dr Peter H Diamandis, inspired by Orteig Prize, which led to Charles Lindbergh's 1927 transatlantic flight, developed X Prize and its purse of $10 million in hopes of fulfilling his own desire to travel in space as well to create new space travel industry; various design approaches and material applications explored; impact of production and consumer costs on marketability of leisure space travel discussed; photos; chart (L)
results.snippet: Russell Blink is squeezing into a spacesuit. It is the real thing, made for Russian astronauts. John Carmack, his fellow dreamer, bought it for $5,000. Like the technologies for making rocket engines that showed up in industrial catalogs, it was,...
results.lead_paragraph: Russell Blink is squeezing into a spacesuit. It is the real thing, made for Russian astronauts. John Carmack, his fellow dreamer, bought it for $5,000. Like the technologies for making rocket engines that showed up in industrial catalogs, it was, simply, out there. ''Isn't it amazing what you can get on eBay these days?'' Mr. Carmack says with a wicked smile.

results.abstract: Interview with Dr Sally K Ride, first woman in space, explores her personal involvement with both shuttle disaster investigations and her experience and knowledge of NASA; she explains how, with both Challenger and Columbia shuttles, reoccurring non-catastrophic defects came to be taken for granted and resulted in disaster; also contends NASA's shift in internal culture which resulted in NASA Adminstrator Dan Goldin's emphasis on going faster, better and cheaper from 1992 to 2001, also influenced personnel, enabling them to make assumptions rather than root out solutions to problems or underlying issues; photos (L)

headline.main: A CONVERSATION WITH/Sally Ride; Painful Questions From an Ex-Astronaut

results.snippet: Though she is a true pioneer, Dr. Sally K. Ride, the first American woman in space, strode into a hotel lobby here this month and went unnoticed. Dr. Ride, 52, enjoys going about life with a degree of anonymity.     After her flights in 1983 and...
results.lead_paragraph: Though she is a true pioneer, Dr. Sally K. Ride, the first American woman in space, strode into a hotel lobby here this month and went unnoticed. Dr. Ride, 52, enjoys going about life with a degree of anonymity. After her flights in 1983 and 1984, Dr. Ride, at the time one of the most famous women on earth, rejected most product endorsements, books and movie offers that came her way.

results.abstract: Excerpts from report of Columbia Accident Investigation Board; drawing; listing of panel's members

headline.main: Excerpts From Report of the Columbia Accident Investigation Board

results.snippet: Following are excerpts from the report of the Columbia Accident Investigation Board, which was released yesterday. The full text is online at nytimes.com/columbia.    The Board Statement      For all those who are inspired by flight, and for the...
results.lead_paragraph: Following are excerpts from the report of the Columbia Accident Investigation Board, which was released yesterday. The full text is online at nytimes.com/columbia. The Board Statement For all those who are inspired by flight, and for the nation where powered flight was first achieved, the year 2003 had long been anticipated as one of celebration -- Dec. 17 would mark the centennial of the day the Wright Flyer first took to the air. But 2003 began instead on a note of sudden and profound loss. On Feb. 1, Space Shuttle Columbia was destroyed in a disaster that claimed the lives of all seven of its crew. . . .
